image.altText: GettyImages-2164679482

props.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus pushes Katie Ledecky all the way in a classic 800m final, after Australia earlier secured more gold via the men's tennis doubles. Follow live.

title.children: Titmus claims 800m silver as American champ Ledecky adds to her Olympic legend

image.altText: A woman with dark hair smiling and a man with blond hair and pursed lips

props.synopsis: The Harris campaign said Mr Trump was trying to back out of a debate that had been set to run on a rival network.

title.children: Harris, Trump disagree on presidential debate, as Trump proposes Fox News event

image.altText: A street sign that reads 'Wall St' in foreground of USA flag

props.synopsis: There are genuine concerns the world's largest economy is heading toward a recession, and the fear is gripping global financial markets.

title.children: 'We are being tossed around on a sea of volatility': Fears US economy headed towards recession

image.altText: Three different images of Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: Looking back over past Garma festivals, the prime minister appears to be presenting in a very different way than he did three years ago.

title.children: Three years, three Garma festivals, and three different versions of Anthony Albanese

image.altText: Vladimir Putin is embraced by a woman wearing a pale blue top. They're standing at the bottom of airplane stairs.

props.synopsis: Eight prisoners, whose crimes included murder, espionage, hacking and fraud, were returned to Russia in the largest prisoner swap between the West and Russia since the Cold War.

title.children: With a hug from Putin, a stark prediction came true as horrified victims watch on

image.altText: A boxer in a blue outfit does a backflip in the ring.

props.synopsis: Charlie Senior will leave Paris with Australia's seventh Olympic boxing medal after upsetting Carlo Paalam on a split points decision in their quarterfinal.

title.children: Backflipping boxer Charlie Senior to land rare medal for Australia

image.altText: Grae Morris flexes his muscles after winning windsurfing silver at the Paris Olympics.

props.synopsis: Australia's Grae Morris has won Olympic windsurfing silver, finishing behind Israel's Tom Reuveny in their lightning quick, three-sailor final in Marseille.

title.children: Grae Morris wins silver, Australia's first windsurfing medal in 32 years

image.altText: Matthew Ebden and John Peers hold Australian flags above their heads on court after winning Paris Olympics double gold medal.

props.synopsis: Matthew Ebden's Paris Olympics campaign started with a 6-0, 6-1 loss against Novak Djokovic, and ends with Australia's second-ever tennis gold medal alongside John Peers in the men's doubles.

title.children: From celebrating one game to celebrating gold: Matt Ebden's Paris journey ends in historic victory with John

image.altText: An excavator sinking into mud at a mine.  A large dozer is being used to drag it out.

props.synopsis: The 48-year-old was working at the Byerwen surface coal mine this morning near Glenden in the Bowen Basin, about 200 kilometres west of Mackay.

title.children: Worker dead after accident at coal mine in north Queensland

image.altText: a middle-aged male police officer in uniform outdoors

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's police commissioner has delivered an apology to First Nations people and pledged to "eliminate racism" within the force during a speech at Garma Festival.

title.children: 'I am deeply sorry': NT Police commissioner makes apology to Indigenous people at Garma

image.altText: Bangladeshi activists point fingers at riot police amidst a scuffle during a protest.

props.synopsis: Student protesters in Bangladesh want an ingrained system of nepotism for some government jobs removed and replaced with a merit-based approach but their demonstrations have lead to fatal clashes with authorities — even for those only there to hand out water.

title.children: Bangladeshi students rose up against what they say is nepotism. Then police responded with bullets

image.altText: A photo taken from over the top of the King and Queen showing off their crowns

props.synopsis: Days after he lost his job, the former assistant minister for a republic called the movement to offer reassurance.

title.children: The PM has torpedoed the republic portfolio, but the movement says it understands why

image.altText: Police station shot up in flames

props.synopsis: Protesters attack police and start fires in Sunderland as violence spreads to another English city following a stabbing attack in Southport that left three children dead.

title.children: Protests turn violent in England as unrest spreads after Southport killings

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: So you're back to give this quiz thing another go? Come on then, I promise I won't judge … much.

title.children: Still believe you can beat me at my own game? It's time to play … HARD!

image.altText: The British fantasy author Samantha Shannon, a woman in her early 30s with brunette hair and big eyes, smiling

props.synopsis: Samantha Shannon landed a six-figure publishing deal at the tender age of 20. Her first book, The Bone Season, was a huge hit. So why did she go and rewrite it?

title.children: Samantha's version: Why a bestselling British fantasy author is rewriting her old books

image.altText: A woman in red leotard mid-handstand on the vaulting apparatus.

props.synopsis: US great Simone Biles wins the vault final to clinch her third gold medal of the Paris Games, dominating the competition with her signature Biles II vault.

title.children: Biles soars to third Paris gold medal with vault triumph

image.altText: Players stand together and hold their medals and the Super Netball trophy as they smile for the camera

props.synopsis: The Thunderbirds are queens of Super Netball again, after beating the Vixens 59-57 in a grand final classic.

title.children: 'I had more to give': Thunderbirds win back-to-back titles after signing discarded veteran

image.altText: A group of men throw peace signs for the camera

props.synopsis: Iran's Revolutionary Guards says revenge for the killing of the Hamas leader will be "severe".

title.children: Iran says Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed by short-range projectile

image.altText: Jim Chalmers blue room

props.synopsis: This week's inflation numbers have spared the Reserve Bank — and the indebted — the spectre of another rate rise. But it hasn't made the problem go away — for the bank or the government.

title.children: Inflation isn't as bad as predicted, but we're now stuck at an inflection point on monetary policy

image.altText: A dog with brown curly hair sits in the middle of a dirt road surrounded by grass.

props.synopsis: Owners of dogs bought from breeder Tasmanian Labradoodles have spoken out about significant problems and large vet bills, after the breeder reached an out-of-court agreement with the RSPCA to shut down immediately.

title.children: 'It wasn't the right dog': Labradoodle owners consider legal action after Tasmanian business shuts amid overbreeding allegations

image.altText: A boxer in red raises her fist in celebration as a boxer in blue looks downcast.

props.synopsis: Two Paris Olympians at the centre of a dispute overshadowing world boxing have every right to compete at the Games as women, according to IOC president Thomas Bach.

title.children: Olympics boxing gender row a 'defamation' campaign, says IOC chief

image.altText: People sit and lie on the floor of a military plane's cabin

props.synopsis: It's a war that has displaced 10 million, created famine and killed at least 18,760 people. Every member of the Sudanese diaspora in Australia has been affected by the carnage.

title.children: Five days in an apartment in darkness: How one Australian escaped Sudan's brutal civil war

image.altText: A man with a white shirt

props.synopsis: US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin has revoked a plea deal agreed to earlier this week with the man accused of being the chief architect of the September 11 attacks, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, and two of his accomplices, reinstating them as death penalty cases.

title.children: Pentagon chief revokes plea deal with three September 11 attack suspects, reinstating them as death penalty cases

image.altText: A group of men throw peace signs for the camera

props.synopsis: Iran's Revolutionary Guards says revenge for the killing of the Hamas leader will be "severe".

title.children: Iran says Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed by short-range projectile

image.altText: People gather around a parked ambulance in Mogadishu

props.synopsis: A suicide bomber and gunmen attack a busy beach in the Somali capital, killing 32 people and injuring scores more in one of the country's deadliest attacks in months.

title.children: Terrorists kill at least 32 people in attack at Mogadishu beach

image.altText: A woman delivering a speech.

props.synopsis: Kamala Harris secures the delegate votes needed to clinch the Democratic US presidential nomination and become the first woman of colour at the top of a major party ticket.

title.children: Kamala Harris secures delegate votes needed to become Democratic nominee

image.altText: A close-up head and shoulders shot of Linda Reynolds arriving at court in Perth wearing glasses and a black jacket and top.

props.synopsis: The first day in the high-stakes trial in the WA Supreme Court has seen Linda Reynolds lawyer pick apart several claims by Brittany Higgins after she reported being raped in Parliament House.

title.children: What we learned from the first day of Linda Reynolds' defamation trial against Brittany Higgins

image.altText: hands holding Australian cash notes

props.synopsis: New data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows household spending has fallen by 0.5 per cent for June after two consecutive rises.

title.children: Australians households are spending less. Here's what they're cutting back on

image.altText: Buildings in the backdrop, next to a Lebanese flag flying in Beirut.

props.synopsis: Australians in Lebanon say they've been left "stranded" trying to exit Lebanon amid renewed advice from the federal government to evacuate the country. But many say they've been left in the dark after being told the airport is closed.

title.children: 'Stranded' Australians holidaying in Lebanon say they can't get home amid evacuation orders

image.altText: A black sign with 'CFMEU Victoria' written on it, hanging on a construction site.

props.synopsis: Construction bosses and building industry whistleblowers fearful of retribution will be free to speak out against the CFMEU under cover of a potential parliamentary inquiry amid concern existing workplace regulators lack investigative teeth and protections.

title.children: Fair Work takeover of CFMEU 'not enough' say critics calling for greater witness protections

image.altText: The Eiffel Tower lit up with the beach volleyball stadium in the foreground and a sunset

props.synopsis: Paris 2024 has embraced its most famous landmark in the most spectacular way, giving rise to one of the most iconic of Olympic venues.

title.children: 'This is a spectacle': Athletes and celebs flock to one of the most iconic venues in Olympics history

image.altText: Saya Sakakibara holds her head and cries

props.synopsis: Saya Sakakibara has endured things as an athlete that many would ever recover from — but her Olympic gold medal is a testament to her strength, and that of her entire family.

title.children: The happy tears of Sakakibara's Olympic gold are a testament to her endurance in the face of adversity

image.altText: A dog in an orange tutu

props.synopsis: Pet owners are sacrificing spending in other areas of their lives to afford luxury pet items as a form of escapism in the cost-of-living crisis, according to researchers.

title.children: Miss Mia the cavoodle has more shoes than her owner, part of a trend of spoiled pets
